title: First Nuclear: Powering the future of clean energy with SMRs | Innovation News Network
text:
First Nuclear Corp. is the future of clean energy through the innovative use of small modular reactors (SMRs).
As part of the First Hydrogen family, First Nuclear aims to produce green hydrogen from SMRs efficiently and sustainably, contributing to global decarbonisation efforts.
Through the utilisation of nuclear energy, sustainable green hydrogen is produced, paving the way for the broader initiative of a zero-emission planet.
Compact and scalable small modular reactors
First Nuclear’s SMRs are compact, scalable, and capable of providing a continuous, weather-independent power supply.
By integrating these advanced nuclear technologies, we ensure a stable and cost-effective green hydrogen production process.
This approach not only supports the growing demand for clean energy but also aligns with global regulatory and market trends.
The hydrogen-as-a-service model
As part of the First Hydrogen family, First Nuclear is integrated with the company’s hydrogen-as-a-service (HAAS) model.
This system enables the delivery of a seamless energy ecosystem, allowing businesses and communities to transition smoothly to clean energy.
Partnership with the University of Alberta
First Hydrogen’s partnership with Dr Muhammad Taha Manzoor of the University of Alberta will further propel the development of SMR technology.
This strategic initiative aims to optimise reactor fuel materials and design in response to the surging global energy demand driven by artificial intelligence (AI) data centres.
AI data centres, which consume up to ten times more power than traditional facilities, are reshaping the global energy landscape.
With electricity demand from data centres expected to double by 2030 – reaching 945 terawatt-hours according to the International Energy Agency – First Hydrogen’s focus on SMR technology represents a timely and vital solution.
The partnership recently expanded to focus on fuel reactor materials, reactor design and reactor design optimisation.
